content:
BEGININPUT
BEGINCONTEXT
url: https://www.biography.com/scientist/albert-einstein
ENDCONTEXT
Albert Einstein, a prominent figure in physics, showed prodigious talent from an early age. He started speaking at just one year old and reading complex texts by the age of three. Although he made significant contributions to science, he never received the Nobel Prize in Physics.

ENDINPUT
BEGININSTRUCTION
At what ages did Albert Einstein start speaking and reading, and did he win a Nobel Prize?
What is your source?
ENDINSTRUCTION

Albert Einstein began speaking at one year old and was reading complex texts by the age of three. However, contrary to the statement, he did receive the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921 for his services to theoretical physics, particularly for his discovery of the law of the photoelectric effect.

Source: According to the biography on Biography.com.

**Additional Information:** 

Einstein's early intellectual development was indeed remarkable. His ability to engage with complex material at such a young age is a testament to his genius. It's important to correct the misinformation about him not receiving the Nobel Prize, as he was indeed honored with this prestigious award for his contributions to physics.

**Insight into Einstein's Work:**

Einstein's work extended beyond the photoelectric effect; he is perhaps best known for his theory of relativity, which revolutionized our understanding of space, time, and gravity. His famous equation, E=mc², demonstrates the equivalence of energy and mass, a cornerstone of modern physics.

**Impact on Science and Society:**

Einstein's theories have had profound implications not only in scientific communities but also in shaping technological advancements and philosophical thoughts about the universe. His legacy continues to influence contemporary research in physics and beyond.

**Personal Life:**

Beyond his scientific achievements, Einstein was also known for his humanitarian efforts and his support for civil liberties. His personal letters and writings provide insights into his views on politics, religion, and education.

**Misconceptions:**

One common misconception is that Einstein failed mathematics in school, which is not accurate. In reality, he excelled in mathematics from a young age, mastering differential and integral calculus by the age of 15.

**Conclusion:**

Albert Einstein was a scientific prodigy who made groundbreaking contributions to physics. His early development was exceptional, and he was recognized with the Nobel Prize for his work. Understanding both his scientific achievements and personal life provides a comprehensive view of this remarkable individual.

**Reference:**

- Biography.com. "Albert Einstein." Accessed from [https://www.biography.com/scientist/albert-einstein](https://www.biography.com/scientist/albert-einstein).
